bib_record.title: Decay widths of highly excited Ra compound nuclei

free_txt: Experiments were carried out at the
Compound nucleus decay widths. Neutron widths
and fission times of highly excited compound nuclei.
The recoil nuclei delivered to the separator
focal plane first passed a pair of broad aperture
timing detectors. These detectors provided the
measurement of the recoil time of flight along a path
of 50 cm with a resolution of 0.5 ns. Then, the recoil
nuclei were implanted into an eight-strip Si detector
having an active surface of 50 x 70 mm2. This detector
provided a rough estimation of the recoil energy and
the detection of the a decay of the implanted recoils
with an energy resolution of 30 keV for a particles in
the energy range of 5-9 MeV. The recoil nuclei were
identified according to their a decay energy and
The beam energy was measured with a Si
counter which detected the beam ions scattered from the
target at 30 degree.  The non-ionization energy loss
and loss of energy in the "dead" surface layer of the
detector were not taken into account.
The uncertainty includes the errors in the
measurements of the separation efficiency, beam doses
Experiments were carried out at the
192 and 225 MeV. The beam energy was varied in steps
of 3-6 MeV by making use of Al and Ti degraders. The
intensity of the beam passing through the target was
limited at a level of 2.E+11 1/sec and was measured by
The thickness of each target was measured by the  X-ray
fluorescence analysis just after the manufacture of the
target and after the completion of irradiations. For
all the targets the results of the two measurements
